title: Protocols for endothelial cell isolation from mouse tissues: brain, choroid, lung, and muscle
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Brain endothelial cell isolation
Timing: 5 h 30 min – 6 h. For preparation of brain digestion buffer, 30 min. For digestion of brain tissue, 1 h 30 min. For myelin depletion using murine Myelin Removal MicroBeads, 75 min. For endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACS, 1–2 h.
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A shows a detailed scheme of brain ECs isolation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/996-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. EC isolation from mouse brain
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from brain.
(B) Representative FACS plots for the gating strategy to sort ECs from brain based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of brain digestion buffer
The following protocol, describing the isolation of brain ECs, includes the use of the Neural Tissue Dissociation kit (P) (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-092-628), which allows mechanical and enzymatic dissociation of brain tissue before removal of myelin (as described previously (Vanlandewijck et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20])). Reagents of this kit need to be prepared in advance according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/neural-tissue-dissociation-kits.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/neural-tissue-dissociation-kits.html#gref]). The protocol is designed to process the entire brain (without olfactory bulb). Described volumes are optimized for the protocol and suffice for 2 (pooled) adult murine brains.
Digestion of brain tissue
Prepare enzyme mix 1 (mix 5.7 mL of buffer X with 150 μL of enzyme P from the Neural Tissue Dissociation kit (P) (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-092-628)) and equilibrate to 37°C.
Before dissecting the brain, perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/min for 5 min.
Remove the brain surgically and place it in ice-cold Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM, high glucose, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11965092) supplemented with 1× penicillin/streptomycin (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#15140122).

Transfer the dissected brain to a Petri dish chilled on ice and mince the tissue with a scalpel blade until no more large pieces remain. The pieces should be small enough to pass through a cut P1000 pipette tip (approx. 0.8 mm diameter).
Transfer the brain pieces to a 15 mL conical tube with a cut P1000 pipette tip and mix them with enzyme mix 1.
Incubate for 17 min at 37°C on a tube rotator (e.g.: HulaMixer™ Sample Mixer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#15920D)) (max. 20 rpm).
During incubation prepare enzyme mix 2 (mix 60 μL of buffer Y with 30 μL of enzyme A from the Neural Tissue Dissociation kit (P)).
Take the cell suspension from the tube rotator and add enzyme mix 2.
Mix the suspension with a Pasteur pipette by pipetting up and down (10 times).
Note: When clogging occurs, remove the clog by tapping the tip of the Pasteur pipette against the bottom of 15 mL conical tube until the clog resolves.
Critical: The suspension should pass through the Pasteur pipette without clogging before proceeding to the next step.
Incubate for 12 min at 37°C with slow rotation (10 rpm) on the tube rotator (e.g.: HulaMixer™ Sample Mixer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#15920D)).
Pass the cell suspension firmly, but without creating bubbles or foam, through a 20G needle (use a 1 mL syringe). Repeat this step approximately 10 times.
Critical: The cell suspension should pass through the needle without clogging, and no major tissue pieces should be visible after this step.
Incubate the cell suspension for an additional 10 min at 37°C with slow rotation (10 rpm) on the tube rotator (e.g.: HulaMixer™ Sample Mixer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#15920D)).

Transfer the cell suspension to a 50 mL conical tube, add 40 mL of ice-cold HBSS (containing Mg2+, Ca2+) and filter through a 70 μm cell strainer.
Critical: From this moment on, the cell suspension should always be kept at 4°C.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 50 mL conical tube, keep the pellet at 4°C.
Repeat steps 2n and 2o two more times for a total of three cycles of centrifugation.
Myelin depletion using murine Myelin Removal MicroBeads
Pool the pellets from steps 2n to 2p resuspend in 3600 μL Wash Buffer and add 400 μL Myelin Removal Beads II (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-096-733).
Mix and incubate at 4°C for 15 min.
Note: Process fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Add Wash Buffer to a total volume of 40 mL.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
During the centrifugation prepare 3 collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Resuspend the pellet in 6 mL of Wash Buffer.
Add 1 mL of the cell suspension on each column (keep the rest of the cell suspension, ± 3 mL).
Critical: Collect the eluent containing the cells.
After the suspension has run through the column, wash the column twice by adding 1 mL of Wash Buffer once the column reservoir is empty.
Critical: Collect eluent to the conical tube from step (3f). This fraction contains ECs.
Prepare another 3 LS columns and repeat the procedure for the remaining sample (± 3 mL left).

Centrifuge the total eluent at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Pool the pellets in 2 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Note: In case the sample is too viscous or contains clumps, filter through a 40 μm cell strainer to prevent clogging of columns in the next steps (do not filter if not necessary).
Mix well and incubate for 20 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and MS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-201) according to the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared MS column through a 40 μm cell strainer.

Wash the MS column 3 times with 0.5 mL Wash Buffer, adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step 4f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or can be discarded if not further needed.
Remove the MS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipet 1 mL Wash Buffer onto the MS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
FACS
Critical: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.
Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use the cells from, e.g.: CD31-negative fraction, to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 500 μL Wash Buffer-based staining solution containing:
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g.: CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g.: CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g.: eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain the cells for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.
Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD45-/CD31+ cells to collection tubes.
Note: To ensure high viability of ECs, sort the ECs to an Eppendorf tube containing collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401).
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD31+ brain ECs.
Choroid endothelial cell isolation
Timing: ∼5 h 30 min. For preparation of choroid digestion buffer, 30 min. For digestion of choroid tissue, 1 h 30 min. For immune cell depletion using CD45 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACS, 1–2 h.
Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A shows a detailed scheme of choroid ECs isolation.

(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from choroid.
(B) Representative FACS plots for the gating strategy to sort ECs from choroid based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of choroid digestion buffer
Right before isolation prepare choroid digestion buffer containing:
Supplemented KnockOutTM DMEM-medium (see details in section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’)
0.3% (w/v) Collagenase I
0.25 U/mL Dispase
7.5 μg/mL DNAse I
table:files/protocols_protocol_996_3.csv
Store the freshly prepared choroid digestion buffer at 4°C until needed.
5 mL of choroid digestion buffer suffices for choroids from 6 adult mice.
Digestion of choroid tissue
Note: prior transcardial perfusion is not required for isolation of choroid ECs.

Note: We suggest to perform dissection of choroids as follows: Sacrifice mice by cervical dislocation and collect eyes by inserting scissors along the eye into the orbital cavity. Cut the four optical muscles and the optic nerve, which appear as a white cord behind the eye. Then place the eyes in PBS and remove periocular tissue under a microscope. Dissect the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)-choroid-sclera complex from the enucleated eyes by peeling off the vitreous body and retina.
Transfer dissected choroids to a 50 mL conical tube containing 5 mL of choroid digestion buffer.
Pipet the choroids vigorously using a P1000 micropipette.
Incubate in a 37°C water bath for 30–40 min.
During the incubation, pipet the choroids vigorously using a P1000 micropipette every 5–10 min.
Stop the enzymatic reaction by adding 5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Filter the cells through a 100 μm cell strainer into a new 50 mL conical tube.
Rinse the used conical tube with an additional 3 mL of Wash Buffer and filter the suspension through the 100 μm cell strainer.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 15 mL conical tube and centrifuge at 300 g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant and wash the cells with 5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Immune cell depletion using CD45 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD45 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-052-301) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Note: We suggest to resuspend cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD45 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix well and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and MS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-201) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Rinse MS columns with 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared MS column through a 40 μm cell strainer.
Wash the MS column 3 times with 0.5 mL Wash Buffer adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Collect the eluent from steps 8f and 8g to the conical tube. This fraction contains ECs.
Centrifuge the total eluent (CD45-negative fraction) at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells resuspend cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and MS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-201) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared MS columns through a 40 μm cell strainer to remove potential cell aggregates in order to prevent clogging of the column.
Wash the MS column 3 times with 0.5 mL Wash Buffer adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step 9f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or can be discarded if not further needed.
Remove the MS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipet 1 mL Wash Buffer onto the MS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.

Lung endothelial cell isolation

Timing: ∼5 h For preparation of lung digestion buffer, 30 min. For digestion of lung tissue, 1 h. For immune and epithelial cell depletion using CD45 and EpCAM murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACS, 1–2 h.
Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A shows a detailed scheme of lung ECs isolation.

Figure 3. EC isolation from mouse lung
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from lung.
(B) Representative FACS plots for the gating strategy to sort ECs from lung based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of lung digestion buffer
Right before isolation prepare lung digestion buffer containing:
Supplemented KnockOutTM DMEM-medium (see details in section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’)
0.1% (w/v) Collagenase II
0.25% (w/v) Collagenase IV
15 μg/mL DNase I
table:files/protocols_protocol_996_4.csv
Store freshly prepared lung digestion buffer at 4°C until needed.
5 mL of lung digestion buffer suffices for lungs from 1 adult mouse.
Digestion of lung tissue
Before dissecting the lungs, perform transcardial perfusion via the right ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/min for 5 min.
Dissect the lungs, cut the lungs (with small scissors or scalpel blade) into single lobes and rinse on a Petri dish with ice-cold PBS.
Place the lung lobes of 1 mouse in a gentleMACS C tube (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-237) with 5 mL of lung digestion buffer. Keep the tube and the digestion buffer on ice.
Critical: Make sure the tube is closed tightly.
Put tubes in a MACS™ Dissociator (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-235):
Run m_lung_01 protocol (pre-programmed by manufacturer).
Incubate sample in digestion buffer in a 37°C water bath for 30 min.
Note: Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Run m_lung_02 protocol (pre-programmed by manufacturer).

Filter the sample through a 40 μm cell strainer into a 50 mL conical tube, rinse the strainer with 5 mL Wash buffer (use a P1000 micropipette for both steps) and transfer the filtered suspension to a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 250 g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 5 mL Wash Buffer, pipet up and down using a P1000 micropipette.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 250 g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.
Immune and epithelial cell depletion using CD45 and EpCAM murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD45 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-052-301) and EpCAM MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-105-958) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend cells in 80 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]; https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd326-epcam-microbeads-mouse.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd326-epcam-microbeads-mouse.html#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells, resuspend cells in 80 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD45 MicroBeads and 10 μL of EpCAM MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix well and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 250 g for 5 min at 4°C.

During the centrifugation step, prepare collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension onto onto a prepared LS column through a 40 μm cell strainer (to remove potential cell aggregates in order to prevent clogging of the column).
Critical: Collect the unlabeled cells (the eluent) in a 15 mL conical tube (this fraction contains the ECs).
Wash LS column 3 times with 3 mL Wash Buffer, adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Collect eluent from steps 13e and 13f into the conical tube. This fraction contains ECs.
Centrifuge the total eluent at 250 g (CD45, EpCAM-negative fraction) for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells resuspend cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process the samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.

Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 250 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension onto a prepared LS column through a 40 μm cell strainer and collect the unlabeled cells (the eluent) in a 15 mL conical tube (CD31-negative fraction).
Wash the LS column 3 times with 3 mL Wash Buffer, adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step 14f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or discarded if not further needed.
Remove the LS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipet 5 mL Wash Buffer onto the LS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
FACS
Critical: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.

Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use the cells from, e.g.: CD31-negative fraction, to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 250 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL Wash Buffer-based staining solution containing:
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g.: CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g.: CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g.: eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain cells for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.
Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge the stained cells at 250 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD45-/CD31+ cells to collection tubes.
Note: To ensure high viability of ECs, sort the ECs to an Eppendorf tube containing collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401).
Note: To determine the efficiency of epithelial cell depletion by EpCAM MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-105-958) an antibody against CD326 (EpCAM) can be added to the staining panel (e.g.: CD326 (EpCAM)-PE Monoclonal Antibody (G8.8), eBioscience™ Cat#:12-5791-82; 1:500). However, we would recommend optimization of the staining. We would like to acknowledge that the EpCAM staining is optional and might influence the FACS sorting of ECs.

Figure 4. EC isolation from mouse muscle
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from muscle.
(B and C) Representative FACS plots for the gating strategy to sort ECs from EDL (B) and soleus (C) muscle based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of muscle digestion buffer
Right before isolation prepare muscle digestion buffer containing:
PBS
0.2% (w/v) Collagenase IV
1.25 U/mL Dispase
2 mM CaCl2
table:files/protocols_protocol_996_5.csv
Store the freshly prepared muscle digestion buffer at 4°C until needed.
10 mL of muscle digestion buffer suffices for soleus from 8 adult mice or EDL from 8 adult mice.
Digestion of muscle tissue
Note: prior transcardial perfusion is not required for isolating muscle ECs.
Dissect soleus and EDL muscle from tendon to tendon as is described in (Hakim et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]) (https://www.jove.com/video/50183/evaluation-muscle-function-extensor-digitorum-longus-muscle-ex-vivo[href=https://www.jove.com/video/50183/evaluation-muscle-function-extensor-digitorum-longus-muscle-ex-vivo] (from min 1:57)).
Keep the soleus muscles separate from the EDL muscles for the entire procedure.
Put the muscle tissue on an ice-cold Petri dish containing 1 mL of muscle digestion buffer.
Cut into pieces with surgical blades until a homogenous paste-like slurry is formed.
Note: Process samples fast, keep the cutting time under 10 min in order to keep good viability of the cells.
Put ice-cold muscle digestion buffer (9 mL of digestion buffer per 16 muscles) onto the sample and transfer into a 15 mL conical tube.
Rotate the conical tube on the tube rotator (e.g.: HulaMixer™ Sample Mixer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#15920D)) at 12 rpm for 45 min at 37°C.
Pipet up and down every 15 min with a Pasteur pipette.

Add 10 mL of Wash Buffer to stop the digestion.
Filter through a 70 μm cell strainer and then through a 40 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the sample at 300 g for 20 min, remove the supernatant.
Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e. for up to 1 × 107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix well and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process the samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and MS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat# 130-042-201) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ms-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer.
Apply the cell suspension to the prepared MS column and collect the unlabeled cells (the eluent) in a 15 mL conical tube (CD31-negative fraction).
Wash the MS column 3 times with 0.5 mL Wash Buffer adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.

Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step 18f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or discarded if not further needed.
Remove the MS column from the separator and place onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipet 1 mL Wash Buffer onto the MS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
FACS
Critical: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.
Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use the cells from, e.g.: CD31-negative fraction, to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 500 μL Wash Buffer-based staining solution containing:
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g.: CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g.: CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g.: eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain the cells for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.
Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD45-/CD31+ cells to collection tubes.

Note: To ensure high viability of ECs, sort the ECs to an Eppendorf tube containing collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401).
Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD31+ EDL (B) and soleus (C) muscle ECs.
